item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Biden to Visit Israel Amid Gaza Crisis, as Fears Grow of Wider War
item.description: The trip is a gamble for the U.S. president, who aims to deter Israel’s enemies with a show of solidarity while seeking to ease the plight of Palestinians under Israeli siege in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: At Egypt-Gaza Border, Confusion and Frustration Reign
item.description: Told they could escape Gaza, scores of people with foreign passports gathered at the only border crossing into Egypt, only to find it still closed, as diplomatic efforts floundered.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered at the Rafah border crossing in Gaza on Monday, hoping to cross into Egypt.

item.title: Poland Begins to Look Beyond the Vote, to Unwinding an ‘Illiberal Democracy’
item.description: With most votes counted, the country is on the cusp of a significant change, but there will be much to do and undo.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Michal Dyjuk/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of Poland’s conservative ruling Law and Justice party, after voting during parliamentary elections in Warsaw, on Sunday.

item.title: A Father’s Desperate Search for His Son After Afghanistan’s Earthquake
item.description: Over a week since a major earthquake decimated his village in northwest Afghanistan, Noor Ahmad is on a harrowing hunt to find his 5-year-old.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I am just begging with God,” said Mr. Ahmad, whose son is missing.

item.title: 2 Swedes Killed in Brussels Shooting Described as Act of Terrorism
item.description: The suspect was at large on Monday night as the threat level was raised. Prime Minister Alexander de Croo said the victims were Swedes.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Hatim Kaghat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene of a shooting in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Satellite Photos Show How Russia Could Be Shipping Arms From North Korea
item.description: An analysis released on Monday said the images showed Moscow may be getting weapons from a North Korean port to an ammunition depot near Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rajin harbor in North Korea’s northeastern city of Rason. The harbor is a focus of questions over arms shipments.

item.title: Families of Hamas Hostages Share Their Anguish
item.description: Relatives of those captured or missing express despair at the lack of information, and they are terrified of what an expected Israeli invasion of Gaza may mean for their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Tamir Kalifa
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of Maya Regev, 21, and Itay Regev, 18, watching a news segment about the Israelis kidnapped by Hamas, at their parents’ apartment in Herzliya, Israel. The siblings attended the rave in southern Israel and are believed to have been kidnapped by Hamas militants.

item.title: Milei Called the Pope a ‘Filthy Leftist.’ He Could Be Argentina’s Next President.
item.description: Javier Milei is leading the race to be Argentina’s next president. But he is dogged by his past broadsides against a fellow countryman: Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:credit: Marcos Brindicci/Getty Images
item.media:description: The presidential candidate Javier Milei during a campaign rally last month in Buenos Aires. He describes himself as Catholic, but his attacks on the pope have alienated some people.

item.title: 4 Ukrainian Children Return From Russia After Intervention by Qatar
item.description: Kyiv has said that thousands of children have been separated from their families and taken to Russia, in one of the most painful issues for Ukraine since the start of the war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Thierry Monasse/Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstration in support of the safe return of children taken from Ukraine during the war, in Brussels in February.

item.title: Slaughter at a Festival of Peace and Love Leaves Israel Transformed
item.description: In this massacre of its youth, Israel’s 75-year-old quest for some carefree normalcy met the murderous fury of those long-oppressed Palestinians who deny the state’s right to exist.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen, Sergey Ponomarev and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burned-out cars at the campsite where the music festival was attacked.

item.title: Ukraine Worries That Prolonged War in Gaza May Dilute Global Support
item.description: Slow military progress and cracks in the backing of key allies could also drain vital attention from Ukraine’s battle with Russia, some fear.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian National Guard soldiers on Friday at a military training ground in the Chernihiv region.

item.title: Daniel Noboa, Heir to a Banana Empire, Wins Ecuador’s Presidential Election
item.description: A center-right political outsider with a focus on jobs beat out the leftist candidate in a high-stakes election that was focused on the economy and surging gang violence.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky, José María León Cabrera and Thalíe Ponce
item.media:credit: Santiago Arcos/Reuters
item.media:description: Daniel Noboa, the scion of a banana empire, whose campaign promised change, arrived to vote in Ecuador on Sunday.

item.title: The Schoolyard
item.description: A small image reveals a larger story.
item.dc:creator: Samar Abu Elouf and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: A Pivotal Election in Poland: Here’s What to Know
item.description: Centrist and progressive forces appear to be in the best position to form a new government, according to exit polling. That would be a blow to the governing nationalist coalition.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters on an abandoned building last week in Nowy Sacz, Poland.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden will go to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu extended an invitation to President Biden over the weekend.

item.title: France on Edge After Killing of a Teacher and Hamas Attack
item.description: Another attack at a school, three years after the beheading of a teacher, has heightened anxiety about a new wave of terrorism in an already scarred country.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Denis Charlet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourners gathering in Arras, France, on Sunday, two days after a teacher was killed in a knife attack at a public school in the city.

item.title: Food Aid Sustains Quake-Hit Villages in Morocco, for Now
item.description: The earthquake that struck Morocco on Sept. 8 killed about 3,000 people, and disrupted food supplies for thousands in regions long subject to the vagaries of fickle seasons.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami and Hannah Reyes Morales
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers for the World Central Kitchen are seen working in a field kitchen converted from an olive press processing plant as they prepare thousands of meals a day in Oulad Berhil to deploy to earthquake survivors in the high atlas mountain region in Morocco.

item.title: Netanyahu Chose Limited Strikes Until Now. This Is His First All-Out War.
item.description: In his 15 years as Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu has been seen as risk-averse, avoiding open-ended military engagements and peace initiatives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jacquelyn Martin
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: These Amphibian Children Have a Taste for (Mom’s) Skin
item.description: Caecilians are the first amphibians known to pass on their microbiomes to their offspring.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Quaglia

item.title: Putin Visits China as Moscow and Beijing Reaffirm Ties
item.description: The Russian leader is likely to push for more economic support when he meets with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Parker Song
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arriving in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul Heads to Israel on Tuesday
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has positioned herself as an unflinching supporter of Israel and has forcefully condemned the Hamas terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would be in Israel until Friday on a “solidarity mission.”

item.title: Iran Warns Israel if Attacks Worsen in Gaza
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister spoke after a whirlwind tour of allies in the region. Israel’s northern border with Lebanon is being closely monitored as the first potential flashpoint where the war could spread.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Abbas Salman/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, returned to Tehran after a regional tour that included visits with a top Hamas official in Doha, Qatar; Hezbollah’s leader in Beirut; and the Syrian president in Damascus.

item.title: 10 Stops in 5 Days, Plus an Air Raid Shelter, for Blinken
item.description: The secretary of state’s chaotic trip in the Middle East has underscored the scale and complexity of the diplomatic crisis he faces.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Tel Aviv on Monday. His trip was originally scheduled for two days.

item.title: Biden to Visit Israel as Gaza’s Crisis Worsens Under Siege
item.description: President Biden will make the extraordinary trip on Wednesday as Israel readies a possible invasion of Gaza in response to the worst terrorist attacks in its history.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Edward Wong
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians and dual citizens at the Rafah border crossing in Gaza, hoping for the border to open to cross into Egypt, on Monday.

item.title: Hamas Posts Hostage Video of Woman Abducted From Israeli Music Festival
item.description: The video, of Mia Schem, 21, was the first Hamas has released of any of its nearly 200 hostages. It showed her being treated for an arm injury and speaking to the camera.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An aerial view of a music festival that was the site of a Hamas attack.

item.title: Israel Prepares for Invasion by Using Phone Data to Track Gazans Fleeing
item.description: The Israeli military says the tracking and the call to evacuate are to preserve as many civilian lives as possible during an expected ground invasion, even as deadly airstrikes continue.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aid was distributed to displaced Palestinians in schools in Khan Younis, southern Gaza Strip, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Biden Weighs a Visit to Israel
item.description: Plus the future of salmon farming.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians, including children, are brought to Nasser Hospital after they wounded in Israeli airstrikes on Khan Younes, southern Gaza Strip, on Monday.

item.title: In Legal Peril at Home, Trump Turns to a U.K. Court for Vindication
item.description: On a day when he lashed out at a federal judge in Washington, the former president asked a judge in London to let his lawsuit over the notorious Steele dossier go forward.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump speaking this month in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: U.S. and Israel Focus on Hezbollah’s Next Move After Hamas Attack
item.description: American officials said they believed the deployment of aircraft carrier strike groups has, at least for now, deterred Hezbollah from opening a new front in the war.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Adam Entous
item.media:credit: Hussein Malla/Associated Press
item.media:description: Israel fired artillery along its northern border with Lebanon amid intense clashes with Hezbollah over the weekend and into Monday.

item.title: Social Media Users Accuse Facebook, Instagram of Suppressing Pro-Palestinian Posts
item.description: Meta has cautioned that some content might be temporarily suppressed or suspended as it sifts through millions of posts spreading across its platforms.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: Bill Ford Says U.A.W. Strike Is Helping Tesla and Toyota
item.description: Mr. Ford, the executive chairman of Ford Motor, said nonunion automakers would make gains against Michigan automakers because of strikes by the United Automobile Workers union.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Associated Press
item.media:description: “Ford’s ability to invest in the future isn’t just a talking point,” William Clay Ford Jr. said. “It is the absolute lifeblood of our company.

item.title: Biden Faces Risks in Wartime Visit to Israel
item.description: A presidential trip to Israel at such a critical moment poses enormous challenges for the White House, in terms of both politics and security.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu extended an invitation to President Biden over the weekend.

item.title: Stuck at Gaza’s Border With Egypt
item.description: Scores of foreign nationals, including many U.S. citizens, waited on the Gaza side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt on Monday, hoping for a deal that would allow them to escape.
item.dc:creator: Soliman Hijjy, Sarah Kerr, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Neil Collier

item.title: Yellen Assures Europe That U.S. Will Provide More Funds for Ukraine
item.description: The Treasury secretary reassured allies that the Biden administration was not backing away from Ukraine despite opposition in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Julien Warnand/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen told top European economic leaders on Monday that the United States was not backing away from supporting Ukraine.

item.title: Yehya Sinwar, Hamas’s Leader in Gaza, Is At the Top of Israel’s Target List
item.description: Considered a brutal enforcer within Hamas, he served time in Israeli prison before being released in a 2011 prisoner swap.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa/Reuters
item.media:description: Mr. Sinwar, who is believed to be 60 or 61, grew up in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Martti Ahtisaari, Conflict Negotiator Given Nobel Peace Prize, Dies at 86
item.description: A former president of Finland, he played a prominent role in talks that led to independence for Namibia and an end to “the Troubles” in Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:credit: Peter Morrison/Associated Press/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Ahtisaari in 2000 with Cyril Ramaphosa, the South African labor leader and anti-apartheid activist who later became his country’s president. They were in Belfast, Northern Ireland, to help reinforce the peace agreement signed there in 1987.

item.title: Israel Will Evacuate Towns Near Its Border With Lebanon as Tensions Escalate
item.description: The border has been a longtime staging ground for attacks by Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese group.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Wael Hamzeh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Smoke rising after Israeli Army shelling of a village in Lebanon near the border with Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Twins Are Born in Gaza After Their Mother Flees to the South
item.description: Despite complications with her pregnancy, Nahla Abu Elouf joined the hundreds of thousands evacuating ahead of a possible Israeli ground invasion. Her newborns need formula, but water is scarce.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuha and Fatin, the newborn twins of Nahla Abu Elouf, in a hospital in southern Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: Robert Sapolsky Doesn’t Believe in Free Will. (But Feel Free to Disagree.)
item.description: Shedding the concept “completely strikes at our sense of identity and autonomy,” the Stanford biologist and neurologist argues. It might also be liberating.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.media:credit: Damon Casarez for The New York Times

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Diplomats rush to address the shortages in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike on Gaza City as seen from Sderot, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Biden Administration Seeks Emergency Aid Package for Both Israel and Ukraine
item.description: Aid to Ukraine lapsed last month amid Republican resistance, while aid for Israel in its war with Hamas has drawn bipartisan support in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, last Tuesday in Washington. Mr. Sullivan said on Sunday that President Biden would ask Congress to support a package of aid to both Israel and Ukraine.

item.title: Fearing Escalation, Biden Seeks to Deter Iran and Hezbollah
item.description: The administration has grown increasingly anxious that Israel’s enemies may seek to widen the war with Hamas and has both sent diplomatic messages and deployed military assets to prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Hussein Malla/Associated Press
item.media:description: Israel fired artillery along its northern border with Lebanon on Sunday amid intense clashes with Hezbollah.

item.title: As Israeli Invasion Looms, Diplomats Seek to Meet Gaza’s Dire Human Needs
item.description: The U.S., Egypt and other countries are urging the delivery of food, water and fuel to counter the desperate shortages facing Gaza’s two million residents.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller, Aaron Boxerman and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike on Gaza City as seen from Sderot, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Biden Warns Israel Not to Occupy Gaza
item.description: While the president has stood strongly behind Israel since Hamas attacked, he said on “60 Minutes” that a new occupation of Gaza would “be a big mistake.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said in an interview that Israel should not occupy Gaza, but he did not explicitly say whether Israeli forces should enter the enclave temporarily.

item.title: Gaza’s Hospitals Face ‘Impossible’ Choices With Israel Evacuation Order
item.description: As a widely anticipated ground invasion looms, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The wounded and their families arriving inside Al Shifa Hospital on Thursday.

item.title: Poland Election: Centrists Poised to Oust Law and Justice Party
item.description: The election, seen as one of the most significant in decades, was cast as a choice between the defense of Polish sovereignty and liberal values.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Piotr Nowak/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The leader of Civic Coalition, Donald Tusk, in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday.

item.title: Israelis Gird for Invasion of Gaza Amid Mistrust of Government
item.description: With a ground invasion into Gaza imminent, Israelis are grappling with a total breakdown of trust and a collapse of everything they believed in and relied on.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families evacuating from Sderot, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: F.B.I. Tracks Increased Threats to Jews and Muslims After Hamas Attack
item.description: F.B.I. officials said that they were reaching out to faith leaders to discuss potential threats against their communities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Alex Kent/Getty Images
item.media:description: Additional security outside Temple Emanu-el in New York City on Friday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A Race to Ease the Gaza Crisis
item.description: Plus the myths that sex experts wish would vanish.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Joran van der Sloot Expected to Plead Guilty in Natalee Holloway Extortion Case
item.description: A lawyer for Beth Holloway, the mother of the Alabama teenager whose 2005 disappearance remains unsolved, said the suspect, Joran van der Sloot, had accepted a plea deal.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:credit: Martin Mejia/Associated Press
item.media:description: Joran van der Sloot in Lima, Peru, last June, shortly before being extradited to the United States.

item.title: Gaza’s Hospitals Face ‘Impossible’ Choices With Israel Evacuation Order
item.description: As a widely anticipated ground invasion looms, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wheeling an injured man into Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Thursday.

item.title: Dariush Mehrjui, Iranian Filmmaker, Found Dead With His Wife
item.description: Dariush Mehrjui, 83, one of the pioneers of Iranian cinema’s new wave movement, was found dead, along with his wife, at their home outside Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Kaveh Kazemi/Getty Images
item.media:description: Dariush Mehrjui, left, on the set of his movie “The Pear Tree” in Tehran in the late 1990s.

item.title: How Megafires Are Remaking the World
item.description: In our Pyrocene age, enormous wildfires aren’t merely damaging ecosystems but transforming them.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Afghanistan Struck by Two More Strong Earthquakes
item.description: Herat Province, near the site of three earlier quakes that killed more than 1,000 people in recent days, was shaken violently again early Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Injured people being taken to a hospital after two more earthquakes on Sunday in Herat, Afghanistan.

item.title: Poised for Attack, Israel Steps Up Calls for Gaza Residents to Leave ‘Battle Zone’
item.description: Nearly one million displaced Gazans are facing shortages of food, clean water and shelter, while Americans remain trapped in the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli armored vehicles massed near Erez, Israel, by the Gaza border on Saturday, in preparation for a widely anticipated invasion in coming days.

item.title: Israeli Invasion Plans Target Gaza City and Hamas Leadership
item.description: The goal, according to three senior officers, is to wipe out the top political and military hierarchy of Hamas, the Palestinian group that controls Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on Saturday load shells onto a tank ahead of a possible invasion of the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Schumer Plans Vote of Support Upon Returning From Israel
item.description: A delegation led by Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, will meet with senior Israeli officials to discuss an aid package this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer in Washington this month.

item.title: Louvre and Versailles Emptied as France Raises Guard After Stabbing
item.description: Troops were being mobilized and two major attractions were evacuated in separate alerts after a stabbing attack that killed a teacher and was described by officials as terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters
item.media:description: The Louvre Museum was evacuated on Saturday morning in response to “a written message,” a spokeswoman said.

item.title: Nearly Half of Gaza’s Population Displaced in Humanitarian Crisis
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Palestinians from northern Gaza have left their homes in the past day alone. The U.N. warned the territory was in danger of running out of water.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians who left the northern Gaza Strip making their way south on Friday near the southern city of Khan Younis.

item.title: U.S. Citizens Fleeing Gaza Say the Border Crossing Is Still Closed
item.description: A U.S. official had said that an agreement had been reached to allow Americans safe passage from the blockaded enclave to Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Anna Betts
item.media:credit: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa/Reuters
item.media:description: People gather outside the Rafah border crossing with Egypt in the hope of getting permission to leave Gaza.

item.title: New Zealand Defeats Ardern’s Party, Electing Conservative Coalition
item.description: The rightward shift came as voters punished the party once led by Jacinda Ardern for failing to deliver the transformational change that it had promised.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Fiona Goodall/Getty Images
item.media:description: Christopher Luxon, the leader of the National Party, meeting voters in Morrinsville, New Zealand, on Friday.

item.title: On the Front Lines, an Israeli University Grieves and Readies for War
item.description: At Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, dorms turned into barracks and medical students manned emergency rooms. Dozens from the university community were killed in the Hamas attacks.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Tamir Kalifa
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
